section-block.rac_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Most of the fruits and vegetables we eat are picked by farmworkers. Let’s thank the people who work so hard to bring us food!

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64876-8. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. From Our Hands with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2020 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Review that letters have names and special sounds. Practice the beginning sounds in penguin, tiger, vest, and zebra.
Invite children to sing a song about healthy food to the tune of “Old McDonald Had a Farm.” Replace farm animal names with fruit and vegetables.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read From Our Hands.
Pablo loves reading informational texts about food we eat and where it comes from! This book is about farmworkers who gather fruits and vegetables for us to eat.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The fruits you like so much are picked by farmworkers. Which fruits do you like?
Which of these yummy fruits do you like to eat?
Tap your mouth if you have ever eaten a yellow squash. A red tomato? Green beans?
Look at the tomatoes. Who can come and point to the t in tomatoes? Tomatoes grow on vines. Who can come and point to the v in vines?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit Tt and Vv Alphabet Cards.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When the fruits and vegetables are ready to eat, who harvests them?
Look at the tomatoes. Who can come and point to the t in tomatoes? Tomatoes grow on vines. Who can come and point to the v in vines?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I like to eat green beans.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences describing several healthy foods you like to eat.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you like to eat apples?
How do you feel when you eat fruits and vegetables?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Having early positive associations to healthy foods makes it easier for children to try fruits and vegetables. Playing games, singing songs, and reading books about different fruits and vegetables will help encourage children to try foods rich in nutrients.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk and Share
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a conversation about how people like to talk and share ideas when they sit and eat with friends or families. Ask children to tell what things they like to discuss when they talk and share with friends at preK.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s think about our Mind Builder as we reread From Our Hands.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Big Book
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s talk about and share our ideas about the important work farmworkers do.
Clifford loves to read about the work people do.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s talk about and share our ideas about what we read and the important work farmworkers do.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Two girls are sharing an orange. What do you think they are talking about? (MB)
Look at all the fruits. What ideas can you share about the colors of the fruits?
What ideas can you share about the work these important workers do? (MB)
What positive thing could you say about the eating fruits and vegetables? (MB)
This farmworker looks like she is celebrating her good work. How does this positive attitude help her? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Assign children to groups of four for a Talk and Share Party. Explain that they will be talking about what fruits and vegetables they like to eat Then set a timer for a few minutes. Ask children to start the party. After the time is up, call the children together and have them tell what their groups talked about at their Talk and Share Party.
Transcribe children’s ideas as they share ideas about the important work of farmworkers.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Henry Ford once said, “If you think you can, you can. If you think you can’t, you can’t. Either way, you are right.” Create a nurturing environment that encourages positive thinking. (Epstein, 2007)

section-block.rac_body-text: Let’s be consumers. Consumers buy things. Show toy fruits and toy money, one at a time. Raise your hand if you would like to buy this apple?
Say two words and ask children to name another word that begins with the same sounds: penguin, peach; tiger, turtle; vest, vase; and zebra, zipper.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the informational text From Our Hand.
Pablo loves reading From Our Hands because it gives us information about the people who pick the fruits and vegetables we eat.
This is the question I want you to think about as we read:
How do farmworkers help everyone?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where do you think these people go to buy fruits and vegetables?
What do these farmworkers do so people can buy strawberries and blueberries?
What do farmworkers do before people can buy green beans, tomatoes, and squash?
Where do you think the families went to buy these fruits and vegetables?
Did you think about the information you learned today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: How do farmworkers help everyone?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to draw and write thank you cards for the farm workers that pick the food.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do farmworkers pick fruits and vegetables?
Describe what a day is like for a farmworker who harvests fruits and vegetables.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Emergent writing is a child’s first attempt at writing. Children as young as two years old can imitate writing by drawing and making markings that represent thoughts. This is the beginning of the stages children progress through as they learn to write. This is an important predictor of children’s reading and writing skills.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to name as many fruits and vegetables as they can. Start a discussion on what makes fruit and vegetables healthy.
Have children act out eating different foods as a partner guesses which food they are pretending to eat.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read “Let’s Make Fruit Salad!” It is a recipe!
Pablo loves to read informational texts about making food.
From Our Hands and “Let’s Make Fruit Salad” focus on how we get healthy food to eat. Let’s see what’s the same about these two texts!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show From Our Hands book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept questions:
What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then, use the prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This poster gives directions for making fruit salad. What fruit do you like to eat in a fruit salad?
We need these ingredients to make a fruit salad.
Each step matches a picture. Let’s pretend to wash our fruit. Let’s make the work fun, so let’s sing while we wash. (MB)
Let’s act out peeling a banana.
What do the children use to measure?
What is the last fruit to add?
Let’s pretend we are mixing fruit. Now let’s eat it!
Whose hands do you think picked all the fruit for the salad?

section.rac_body-text: Have children use play or imaginary food to prepare meals.
Provide a writing prompt about how to make a fruit salad and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: “Code-mixing” or combining different language in a single sentence is not a sign of developmental delay. Children who are multilingual are often learning two languages at once. They might only know certain words in one language. Encourage children by pointing out that words can be like fruits mixed together in a salad.

section-block.rac_body-text: Guide children to classify fruits and vegetables only by color. First show the color of a classroom object. Then, invite children to name fruits and vegetables that are that color. Use green, red, yellow, and purple.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book From Our Hands.
This book is an informational text. An informational text tells about real things. Pablo loves to read informational texts about real people!

This week we will read about what farmworkers do to help feed people. As we read the book again, I want you to think about this guiding question: How do farmworkers help you get the food you like to eat?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pretend we are farmworkers! Let’s put out all the fruits the farmworkers picked.
Let’s drive this truck filled with oranges to the market.
Let’s pretend to use our hands to pick the delicious tomatoes off the vine!
Let’s climb our ladder to pick oranges off the tree!
Let’s pretend we are carrying this big bucket of apples. It’s very heavy. Don’t drop it!

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to Turn and Talk.
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do farmworkers help you get the food you like to eat?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about the foods they like and where the foods come from. Have them share their work when they are finished.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do farmworkers pick oranges from the trees?
Farmworkers pick oranges from the tr____ . (trees)
Farmworkers pick oranges from the trees.
What other fruits grow on trees?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Introduce children to new words by using them yourself. Do this by being a walking thesaurus and use synonyms frequently. Often a synonym is more descriptive than the original word. Use sensory words to describe the foods children like to eat: juicy, sweet, crisp, salty, spicy, soft, crunchy, and so on.
